Introduction
==========
CrossCode is the perfect example of why Early Access exists. It gives us an idea of the game the developers have in mind, while allowing us to support them and help them to finish their game. CrossCode is an action RPG, and a shiny pearl in the sea of  trash that's currently swimming in Early Access. There are a lot of systems and features in place and ready to go, such as melee/ranged attacks, dodging, guarding, skill trees, elemental attacks, interacting with the terrain, trading, puzzle-filled dungeons, story scripting, enemy AI and attack patterns, bosses, and more! CrossCode draws heavily from the 16-bit era, and if you've played Secret of Mana or Zelda: A Link to the Past for the SNES, then you'll see the influence easily. The gameplay is very similar to those two games, and it's simply amazing. The current version of CrossCode is a set of demos, one for each mode: Story, Puzzle, and Exploration. I'll go over each one in turn.

Gameplay
==========
First, let's go over Story Mode. In Story Mode, you are introduced to a cast of characters and the game world. I'm not going to spoil anything here, but let's just say it's a premise that's been done before but with a few twists. You begin in a sort of tutorial area, which has you running a character through a small forested area towards a building. Along the way, you are taught the basic controls and basic combat abilities.  Once you reach the building a short dialogue occurs, then the game transitions to a cargo ship where we meet the main player character and the supporting cast. More tutorials occur, such as ranged and melee combat, switches, dodging, and later guarding. You have a melee slashing attack, and a ranged attack that has you shooting spheres. The spheres are able to bounce off walls when charged. The Story Mode demo wraps up after a boss battle that introduces an antagonist who tries to abduct the main character. She is saved by the supporting cast and makes an escape.

Next, we have Puzzle Mode. Puzzle Mode takes you through a typical dungeon that will be implemented into the finished game. This has you hitting switches to open doors, moving boxes to press switches, navigating large rooms to solve puzzles scattered throughout, and ultimately ending up at a boss battle that introduces you to Boss AI scripting. It has 3 phases, the first being the melee phase. It'll be within your melee range, so just attack it normally. Next with Phase 2 it'll move away out of your melee range, so start using your ranged attacks. In the combat area are 2 switches which raise 2 pillars. When the boss starts charging up it super attack, hit one of the switches and hide behind a pillar that pops up. The boss will finish his attack, then hit the switch itself and lower the pillar and resume it's attacks. In phase 3 it gains a shield, which you need to solve a small puzzle to figure out how to bring it down. It involves bouncing your ranged attacks off of bumpers to hit it from behind, shorting out it's shield. Defeating it gives you the option to take on the Final Challenge"

Early Access Review

I'm not sure what it is exactly. Something about this game has just made me want to support it and evangelize it in a way that no other game in the past really has. Maybe it's CrossCode's perfect fusion of classic SNES RPG visuals with slick, modern combat controls. Maybe it's a design so on point it feels like a case study in how to build a game right. Maybe it's that, running entirely in HTML5 and impact.js, it solidly demonstrates that the web browser is now a viable platform for precision-based gameplay. Or maybe it's that despite all of these things, no one seems to realize it exists, and it nearly didn't get funded because of it.

CrossCode is definitely worth your attention, if not as an early access purchase then at least as something to check back on once it's released next year. While I still think Q2 2016 is a very aggressive schedule for a version 1 release and expect it to slip towards the end of the year, RadicalFishGames has shown an impressive amount of dedication, talent, and content thus far, and I fully believe they'll deliver on their ambitions. CrossCode is a poster child for why independent games matter more than ever in a market where AAA relevance is dwindling. It's destined to become a cult phenomenon, reverently mentioned in the same company as Cave Story, Braid, or Fez. I'm highly looking forward to it and you should be too.

======================================CrossCode Read on for the full review!
======================================
TL;DR:
While this game is still in development, and I can't say much, I can say that the demo has me sold, and if you're looking for the next big thing, this just might be it. Give it a purchase if you're okay with waiting for the finished product.

======================================
Pros+ Graphics: Oh my god yes. They're gorgeous!
+ Animation: In a category all of it's own, literally.
+ Music: As good as the graphics!
+ UI: Stylish AND extremely functional.
+ Story: Well written.
+ Levels: Excellently designed with flawless puzzle integration.
+ Combat: Fast paced, varied, excellent.

Cons- So much polish you MIGHT go blind.
- It isn't finished yet! D:

Neutral+/- The combat sequences may tend to drag on. Remains to be seen.

======================================
This one impressed me from the very start. The music, colors, and animation I was greeted with on the title screen alone were all of fantastic quality. Upon entering the game, Crosscode treats you to a wonderful color palette, and a basic mysterious introductory story scene, that gives you a brief briefing of the combat system you'll be working with.

Crosscode, from what I can tell, is a game about an AR MMO where the players are hooked into avatars made from instant matter. There is a physical location in the world starting with Rhombus Square where they can play the game. Their attacks, it seems, effect the physical world, although they can only be seen with AR glasses. It also seems that they are not necessarily prohibited from leaving their designated game zone.

The tutoral will cover all of this and a bit more, as you take on the role of the protagonist Lea, who has amnesia and is going to be playing the game to attempt to recover her memories. The story may be starting to become familiar territory, but aside from a few grammatical mistakes, is excellently written. Likewise, the gameplay is as smooth as can be, with many options for you.

In combat, you can fight with ranged or melee, even to some extent simaltaneously, and both will be needed, but often times you are allowed to use either as you see fit. There will be many RPG features like equipment, a sprawling skill tree reminiscent of Path of Exile, inventory management, levels and experience, etc. The gameplay I've experienced so far reminds me a lot of Golden Sun, in that it's an action-puzzler RPG with excellent graphics, world design, and puzzle elements flawlessly integrated into said world design.

The UI is also flawless, and the developers have made it very easy to navigate. It's stylish but also very functional. The game has full keyboard/mouse and controller support, but goes the extra mile to make keyboard navigation easy. The camera transitions, dialogue, and everything else are smooth and refreshingly simple.

After playing this demo I could not be more excited about the final product-which I will now commence eagerly awaiting. Even more importantly, this demo has made me feel like I have a high degree of assurance this will be a game of the utmost quality.

CrossCode -  a retro action-RPG, promising exciting fast-paced combat, serious puzzle-solving and on top of that a meaty story. So far so good!

Making these kinds of promises as a new development team certainly takes a lot of... courage, but how does CrossCode hold up so far? Thankfully, the current Early Access version is split into three parts, each of which is focused on one of these things:

- Exploration Mode puts you into a large open area populated by monsters. It allows you to get a feel for the game's controls as well as the extensive systems for skills (think FFX's sphere grid, but designed by a sober person) and equipment. Trying to find a large number of hidden chests you get the chance to freely jump and battle your way through the area, all the while learning new techniques and improving the stats of your character. This mode makes up the bulk of the game's current playing time and is I have had a blast playing it. Running and jumping around is just a ton of fun! While it took me a while to get comfortable with the controls during fighting, the feeling you have when you start improve and manage to defeat large mobs of enemies (that just minutes earlier were vanquishing you mercilessly) is incredibly rewarding. The game it reminded me most of is Bastion, which was one of my favorite Indie action games of the last few years, but with the beautifully animated SNES-era graphics it of course also recalls classics such as Terranigma.

- Puzzle Mode shows you an example of what the dungeons of the finished game might look like. It is only a short part of the current version, but it complements the action-y parts very well and gazing into my crystal.. eh... sphere I foresee a lot of fun once these puzzles get properly integrated into the main narrative. Think Alundra, but with a feeling that you have actually solved the puzzle instead of exploiting the game's jump physics (nah, I'm just breaking your.. stones here, Alundra, you're a great game)

- Story mode mostly works as a tutorial for the controls and an introduction to some of the game's main characters as well as a teaser as the game's larger world and plot. So if you're hoping to get deep into the world of CrossCode already, this might leave you with a severe case of blue testes, but that's not a bad thing in my book. Well I guess it is... should have rephrased that. Anyway, I'd rather have the chance to enjoy the game's style and mechanics now instead of delving into the plot too deeply - that's best left for when the game is actually finished.

SO GET TO THE POINT, SHOULD I BUY CROSSCODE NOW?
Well, maybe! (Ooh

See, part of me wants to go and make everybody buy this now, but I think that would do the game a disservice. CrossCode is certainly not a finished game at this point, even if the controls, animation and soundtrack already have a very high level of polish. And the current price is certainly at the level (or likely even above) where the finished product will be sold next year. So I would suggest this: if this sounds like your kind of game and you're curious to experience a game as it goes from its early stages to a fully fleshed out product - get it now! If you're interested but already don't have the time to play half the fully-finished games in your backlog? Then put it on your wishlist, follow their regularly updated and very detailed development blog and come back in a year or so. This is not a game that will always be expanded or be significantly cheaper during Early Access.

In short, CrossCode is already a ton of fun, and if the devs keep their eyes on the .. prize then this should turn out to be a great game once it's done.


Full disclosure: I backed this game during the Indiegogo campaign and I'm friends with some of the devs, so I might not be entirely trustworthy. But for what it's worth, I promise you that I wouldn't have written any of this if I didn't enjoy the game and thought it deserved a wider exposure. AND I DIDN'T EVEN SAY BALLS ONCE. EXCEPT FOR NOW. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I came about CrossCode as a web-based game, completely designed in HTML5, and therefore featured on Chrome Experiments. Back then, it wasn't even an RPG; it was basically a simulation of the aiming engine, a clone of the early tutorial now present in the current version of the game. As little of a resemblance that web-version has with the current state of the game, it did show the talent and ambition of the developers, and what has been added since is astonishing.

Astonishingly good. Although there are some loose ends in the story still, this is due to the fact the game is actually in Early Access as of writing this review. And already now, it's worth the $20.

Why? Well, first of all, the game looks extremely polished already. The pixelated sprites 'fit' each other, controls have been neatly arranged and the game mechanics up until now have been executed to near perfection.

These mechanics are quite plentifully present, actually. Every enemy has specific attacks and weaknesses, and even different 'evolutions' of itself. The attacking system is as elegant as it is challenging; WASD to move, left-click to hit, right-click to dodge/block. That's it. The maps have been built in such a way it is relatively easy to traverse through for a quick sweepthrough, but provides quite the challenge when going for the semi-hidden presents scattered all over the maps.

Now, of course, as it is still in development, the main plot of the story is finished in roughly half an hour. After that, you're kind of being released into the world, in order for you to explore on your own. Quests can be completed, ranging from collecting items to beating enemies. Because of the layout of the maps, some of those can take some time; not in an annoying way though, as you're mostly being busy trying to work out how to get to a certain ledge.

The only negative in this version is that the 'open-world' feeling of the game is somewhat limited. This is caused by the facts that certain buildings aren't visitable, some paths are blocked, and the world is consisting of only 5 maps (a city, 2 trails, the tutorial map and the main hub - these are rather extensive, though!). I'm not only expecting, but quite frankly plain confident the devs will be able to make that point go away.

The game is already a blast to play through, and with the constant stream of content updates, it'll only get better.

In short: Buy it now. This might be one of those underestimated games, deserving a lot more exposure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Edited for my final impression on my early review of the game!)

CrossCode is a fast-paced 2D retro RPG game where you start playing as a 'jack of all trades' character in a MMORPG world and your main objective is to master all 4 elements and solve the mysteries. So, how well does the game runs in terms of its presentation, gameplay, story?

Pros:
+Vivid and beautiful graphics with smooth 60 FPS animation
+Soothing and exhilarating soundtrack and perfectly syncronised audio
+Simple and easy-to-learn combat mechanics with many combos that can be freely executed
+Variety of puzzles you can solve that is not too challenging but not too easy as well
+Very well designed world environment that allows to traverse around easily
+Nicely written and interesting plot with a mix of futuristic sci-fi and dungeon crawler fantasy

Okay that's quite a lot of good sides there but what about the bad sides? Well, to be honest, I don't find any problem during gameplay and I actually enjoy it despite being early access but there are very few that I want to point out.

Cons:
-Some battles can be frustrating at first and the first challenge starts very early
-You need a lot of info on the environment around you and it takes time in order to get from one point to a desired point
-Might experience lag in some points
-Game contents are still small right now

The game is written in HTML 5 instead of C++ or Python but it runs as .exe so I can't tell whether the game runs natively or still relies a lot on a default web browser.

So, is the game finally worth it to buy and play at this point? This game has many potentials here at its beta stage, but unless you're willing to support the developers, I'd say you have to wait until the game is finish developed, polished and ready to be publish as a full game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of this writing, Crosscode is still in Early Access; so many elements of the game are likely to change in the coming months.

What's there is amazing. The art is unbelievable. It's pixel-art by choice, not a needlessly restrictive throwback or cash-in. It's what I wanted the future of gaming to look like in 1994, before 3d and FMV came along and messed everything up.

The music doesn't quite hold up its end of the bargain, but there are great tunes scattered about and it's never a problem--it just doesn't quite match the perfect neo-16-bit splendor of the visuals.

Gameplay is reminiscent of underrated classics such as Terranigma, Beyond Oasis, and Landstalker; though with an interesting ricocheting ranged attack that changes things up a bit and provides for some cool puzzle-solving opportunities.

The writing and story are fun, though the tutorials are a bit wordy for my taste. Depending on the length of the finished game, this may not be an issue, but in an Early Access mode that only lasts a few hours, it's a bit of a drag.

Excellent groundwork has been laid, now let's see the follow-through.

Updated 4/10/2016 to reflect the current state of the game.

Steam is saturated with early access sham games these days. They all release in some kind of beta sandbox state, with the dev house behind it promising the moon and the sun to the community within a year or so. Often enough these products stagnate and never realize any potential" the hype train saw in the game. CrossCode is not another one of these games.

CrossCode is a wonderful action RPG that takes place in an alien world where gamers far away connect to avatar bodies and occassionally throw balls at hedgehogs

recommended: the protagonist (so we're led to believe so far) is suffering a mad bout of amnesia. A floaty head guy tells Lea to play the game to kickstart her memory and following drama involving a giant enemy crab you begin your quest among the peasants to hopefully remember something about your past.\n\nThe developers have done a wonderful job pacing the release of the story along side the development of important gameplay features which has made every new release feel well rounded out and avoids spoiling the end before the game itself is complete. The physics engine underneath everything is so smooth that you'll never feel like you're fighting your character or the environment. Characters in this game have so far been very likeable with colorful (not in the derogatory sense) dialogue and unique personality. Additionally the game has an MMOG-like character party system which works and feels similar to any other MMOG analogue. This might seem minor

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an early access review, so the completed game may differ wildly from what I have seen.

First, the game serves as a massive homage to the 16-bit era of games. It has smooth controls, an easily intuitive UI, and doesn't burden you with massive complexity in terms of gameplay itself. While the current story is limited to the opening bits and one dungeon, it still gives you a great deal of room to explore and play with the game's mechanics.

In terms of the game environment and the bits of story seen, it takes influences from throughout the era, with a few from other eras to better flesh out the story. The world's details are reminiscient of the later 16-bit era games, with great attention to detail, colorful environments, and excellent pallete layering to give a perception of depth. This gives the game's aesthetics a very nostalgic feel without bringing up the era's limitations.

The music, of course, is and is not 16-bit. It is 16-bit as it uses the synthesized sound we remember, but isn't in the fact that it uses modern sound drivers which perfected the digital music compression started in the era. This isn't an insult to the 16-bit era of game music. Many of the best and most beloved video game musics were dome in the 16-bit era (anyone else remember Aria Di Mezzo Caraterre aka the song during the Opera Scene from Final Fantasy VI?).

The game is a complete homage to an era of gaming. An era where video games began to become more complex, an era where games came into their own, and an era which shaped the modern era of gaming.

First of all it's amazing gameplay, also nice art/graphics and scarce content yet(it's in the early access as of the time of writing). Even killing the same enemies again and again is fun due to fast and not too simple combat system.

The gameplay in short is comprised of the following:
You hit enemies with melee attacks and shoot at them at the same time and you dash to dodge and block for defense. You also use varous special skills from time to time of 4 types: shooting skill, melee skill, dash skill and defense skill. There are several variants to choose from of each of the four. Plus from time to time you can apply elemental damage to your attack.

The development of the character is comprised of getting new levels given for killings. With levels the stats grow and you choose passive bonuses and aforementioned special skills. There are also equips.

There's also the beginning of some plot which isn't ready yet. And there isn't much content yet in general. I really hope devs won't abandon the game and will make a lot of new content. Like different enemies, locations, quests and the plot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been keeping up with the development of this game since I got up to the current whereabouts of the story.
Let me start of by saying that this game fulfilled a craving that I think I forgot I had when I was ten years old. See, I always wanted a game with this perfect style of pixel graphics and Kingdom Hearts-esque smoothness of gameplay. I got it now.

Story 8/10
Now listen - the story is not done yet, I can't judge it to its full potential yet. When I got up to the latest part that has been... storied, I almost cried. This is because I wanted to continue playing in its glorious splendor. It surprised me how well fleshed out the events and the dialogue were. It felt like I had been brought back to before the primary concern of making games was money games. It's very clear that real real thought has been put into the story. This rating can only climb.

Gameplay 10/10
What can I say? It is the smoothest game I have ever played. The combat is fun. I like grinding in this game. That never EVER happens. I never genuinely enjoy grinding. This game has perfected 2D action. Seriously. Some AI needs a tiny bit of improvement for newcomers to sink into it softly, but it is going to be perfect. I assure you.

Characters/Environments etc. 10/10
The very real feeling world in the Croissant is absolutely beautiful and lively. It bustles as its creatures move around and it shines as clouds roll over the map. The Ys I-II-esque lighting effects perfectly compliment the beautiful lighting. The environments are mastered and fully enjoyable as even something to look at. The lively environments are well complimented by the alive feelign characters. The little tid-bits of language differences are used very well in compliment to the characters. Relationships are astounding. Every detail is thought out like a Patrick Rothfuss book.

Development 10/10
Truly the best development team I've kept up with. They clearly have drive to make this game. It seems like the game existing is a dream of theirs, not a project. They work on it constantly, and have a friendly relationship with the players.
Recently, they posted that they were delaying an update that almost 1.5's the content already in the game. I was distraught until I read that now it's coming out early may. This is actually pretty fast, needless to say.


I imagine this game will be on my favourite list for years if not decades.

If you have a steam machine, play this game. If not, play it anyway, It's incredible.

Oh boy, Crosscode, where to begin? :) This is a great game that i bought during a sale (25% off) and i don't regret a thing!
If anything, I'm just waiting, nay, drooling for more content.
Well, with that out of the way, what can you expect from Crosscode?
First off, the Music. Ahh. Nice. The music is Beautiful, and reminds me of Snes classics like Chrono Trigger,
Secret of Mana, Secret of Evermore and Illusion of Gaia, and just a bit of Megaman and Xenogears as well :)
As far as gameplay goes, I got used to the controls in almost no time. The controls were smooth and fluid, which is something I like in games like this.
As a side note: I use the keyboard and mouse, but aside from any technical issue, I think you would find it easy to use a controller. Also, an FYI, to use Melee attacks, keep the target cursor near Lea when attacking
(This is for the keyboard and mouse)
Now, The Story. So far, There isn't much yet, as you might notice from other reviews, but, what there is of the story
is really interesting so far. At the moment, the story goes as far as the beginning of bergen trail, and a fight with
another character. after the fight, it wraps up, and you can either do quests or explore all the areas available right now.
The graphics are as advertised, and again, remind me of the snes era games. Nice.
Finally, the Big Question. Is it worth the price? Short anwser is: Maybe. As i mentioned before, i Don't regret buying this game one bit. i'm glad I decided to buy it. but some things work in my favor.
1- I got it on sale, that's always nice(15 bucks instead of 20)
2- I grew up playing these kinds of games. This might seem strange to put in, but there is something to be said for nostalgia when it comes to games. on the other hand, if you never played a snes before, this might your future nostalgia ;)
3- I love the music. No Really. I Love it. When it comes out as a soundtrack, or perhaps on bandcamp(you can check it out on soundcloud right now) i will definitely be buying it.
4- That story. Grahh. Want Moar!
Anyway, the long and short of it is, If Crosscode were complete right now, it would be more then worth that 20$ price
Right now, it might be a little hard to say(since i'm stingy) but honesty, I don't think you'll regret it.
At least until you need an update for the story. XD

Secret of Mana, Secret of Evermore and Illusion of Gaia, and just a bit of Megaman and Xenogears as well :)
As far as gameplay goes, I got used to the controls in almost no time. The controls were smooth and fluid, which is something I like in games like this.
As a side note: I use the keyboard and mouse, but aside from any technical issue, I think you would find it easy to use a controller. Also, an FYI, to use Melee attacks, keep the target cursor near Lea when attacking
(This is for the keyboard and mouse)
Now, The Story. So far, There isn't much yet, as you might notice from other reviews, but, what there is of the story
is really interesting so far. At the moment, the story goes as far as the beginning of bergen trail, and a fight with
another character. after the fight, it wraps up, and you can either do quests or explore all the areas available right now.
The graphics are as advertised, and again, remind me of the snes era games. Nice.
Finally, the Big Question. Is it worth the price? Short anwser is: Maybe. As i mentioned before, i Don't regret buying this game one bit. i'm glad I decided to buy it. but some things work in my favor.
1- I got it on sale, that's always nice(15 bucks instead of 20)
2- I grew up playing these kinds of games. This might seem strange to put in, but there is something to be said for nostalgia when it comes to games. on the other hand, if you never played a snes before, this might your future nostalgia ;)
3- I love the music. No Really. I Love it. When it comes out as a soundtrack, or perhaps on bandcamp(you can check it out on soundcloud right now) i will definitely be buying it.
4- That story. Grahh. Want Moar!
Anyway, the long and short of it is, If Crosscode were complete right now, it would be more then worth that 20$ price
Right now, it might be a little hard to say(since i'm stingy) but honesty, I don't think you'll regret it.
At least until you need an update for the story. XD

This is a wonderful, if currently incomplete 2d hack and slash style rpg. The 8 directional controls are smooth as silk, and the combat system is a challenging but well balanced blend of ranged and melee, against a variety of enemies with equally varying behaviors in an interesting world with a refreshing plot and setting.

The game also manages to incorporate a 3d enviroment where you can hop up onto ledges of varying heights and leap across gaps to parkour and make use of the terrain to survive against enemy ai of higher levels.

Quick reflexes on the keyboard and mouse are required, but the controls are instinctive and easy to use. (Mastering them, on the other hand, is a different matter :D)

When I first found this game for free online in its original demo form, I was very disappointed to find it was only a demo, and was afraid that it would never go anywhere. But then, months later low and behold I found it on steam, and didn't hesitate to buy it. I was overjoyed at the progress that had been made, and eagerly look forward to seeing future updates.
